subs.text: May 19

On Tuesday, in a shady alcove in a great city park, someone who was the spitting image of @RealChalamet tuned his acting chops by offering free performances of Shakespeare monologues for anyone interested who came by. Long, intricate, intimate progressions of thought and emotion. [link]

subs.text: We chatted briefly about the line before “Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow . . . “ when Macbeth realizes he has no time to grieve his wife’s death: “She should have died hereafter; there would have been time for such a word.”

subs.text:
What’s the average age
at which a typical billionaire
first misjudges his ability
to master a complex new field?

PS. Betcha a nickel
the typical billionaire 
doesn’t think there is
any such thing as 
a typical billionaire.

@JoannaBlythman The name of the publication would be useful here. Even better, a link to the article. Are we hearing a bit of a sneer in the writing (eg., the “glibly” part) that might mean it’s an opinion piece rather than reporting? It’s hard to tell from this extract. I’d like to read more.
subs.rawText: @JoannaBlythman The name of the publication would be useful here. Even better, a link to the article. Are we hearing a bit of a sneer in the writing (eg., the “glibly” part) that might mean it’s an opinion piece rather than reporting? It’s hard to tell from this extract. I’d like to read more.

subs.text: Yes, there’s outrage that the Supreme Court’s privacy has been disrupted by a leak. I guess this could pressure and politicize the Court in a new way, but the Court was not free from politics as it was. But exposing the deliberations of government to public view ain’t all bad. [link]
subs.rawText:
Yes, there’s outrage that the Supreme Court’s privacy has been disrupted by a leak.

I guess this could pressure and politicize the Court in a new way, but the Court was not free from politics as it was.

But exposing the deliberations of government to public view ain’t all bad. https://t.co/VnvNrb45MK
